item.description:
"Card Game for 2+ players. Fantasy Combat Theme. Educational: Basic Math Skills for Ages 6 and up"

Fight an opposing wizard with Creatures, Fireballs, and Lightning Bolts. Protect yourself with Shields and Healing spells. Each player starts with twenty-five Magic Points. The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero Magic Points.

name.value: A Song of Ice and Fire: The Adventure Game

item.description:
UNRELEASED GAME

 
 
 Note that all details for this game are preliminary. This game has not been released, and since its announced release date has long since passed, this game might never be released. This listing serves as a historical record; you are invited to submit corrections or update this section if additional information comes to light.

 


Players each play as a unique character from one of the house factions in George R. R. Martin's Westeros universe.

This is an adventure style game where players use a set number of actions per turn to travel, fight, play cards, and rest.

This game is card-driven and the cards allow you to gain items, allies, and stats, as well as attack and hinder your opponents. Many of the cards have conditions which, when successfully met, give you points in three different categories.

The game is divided into three "acts". At the end of Act III, whoever has the highest score in their weakest category wins the game.

This game was first shown at Gencon 2008 where it was available for public playtesting. It was in unpublished prototype form at that time.

link.value: A Song of Ice and Fire

item.description:
From the website:

Link dice across a unique playing field to outscore your opponent.

Chain Gang is simple but challenging dice scoring game. Players roll four dice and then put two of the dice scores into hexes on the score pad to form "chains" of dice. Create the longest chain you can while simultaneously blocking your opponent from making his or her own chains.

The game has been developed by Identity Games in Rotterdam for Robeco as a promotional game.

The goal of the game is to accumulate several victory points. Points are scored in several ways: 
1. By investing a full 100% (in steps of 25%) in a economic sector. 
2. With special strategy cards worth 1 point. When you land on a strategy field you can pick up 1 card.
3. By investing in different areas at the same time around the world. 
4. By investing in all sectors at the same time (regardless of area)

The game shares several similarities with Monopoly, like roll-and-move, buying assets, completing sets, drawing cards when landed on certain fields on the board. There are also some differences, for example you can takeover someone's assets when you land on his field and he has no full set yet.

A card game where one player takes on the role of the Reaper (IRS) and the other players are taxplayers (wordplay on taxpayer). Players try to bluff the reaper on card values (deductions) that can increase money bag values. If the reaper catches a bluff (audit he get the card value for himself. The first player to accumulate 150,000 wins the game.

Forget everything you thought you knew about UNO! Clockwise? Counterclockwise? Nope, it's totally random! This exciting electronic version selects who's next, so you have to stay alert. Did you blink? Uh-oh, you missed your turn and time ran out! It's the fast, crazy game that will keep you guessing , on your toes, and raring to go. And just when you think you can relax and take a breath, you still need to remember to yell "UNO!"

Adds random turn order, timed turns, and the exclusive Slap card to the classic gameplay.

item.description:
From the publisher's intro in the rules:

The Fun Ranching game was created by a 4-H leader of a live-stock club from Albany, Oregon. The details and format of the game were refined by kids from the city involved in her Livestock Club, some with learning abilities. Fun Ranching has three (3) levels to provide equal opportunity for all ages and learning abilities.

THEME: You are living with mom and dad on the OLD HOMESTEAD. They say it is time for you to try ranching on your own. They have authorized the bank to issue each of you $4,000. You may begin BUYING and SELLING Livestock and/or your ranch as soon as the game begins.

THE OBJECT: you are BUYING and SELLING livestock for profit to complete the ranch of your choice.

TO WIN: 1) Own all three (3) ranch properties that complete a ranch. 2) Own the required amount of Livestock to complete a ranch. 3) Have all your bank loans and debts paid in full.

From the box: Duality is an easy to learn two player strategic card game. Be the first to build an unbroken path to your opponent's side. Add or replace cards to improve your path, but be careful, your moves may help your opponent as well.

The goal of Duality is to be the first to form a connected path of your color (black or white) from your side of the table to your opponent's side.

- 1 metal game box
- 1 double-sided instruction sheet
- 43 Duality cards

item.description:
A fun game of bluff for 2-4 players Ages 7 and up, using 33 fact-filled cards on Marvel Super Heroes.

The game play is similar to a card-based version of Liar's Dice. Each player selects a number of cards from their hand, passes to the player on the left and announces e.g. "3 Blue". The receiving player can then accept the statement as truth and take the cards or challenge it as a bluff. If they're right, the active player has to reduce their score by the announced value. If they're right, they must reduce their score. First one to lose 15 points is the loser. Bids must increase until a challenge is made.

The game box has an integrated scoring track.

There are several other versions of this game. The first set consists of Marvel Heroes, Ben 10, Baby Animals, Horses, Monster Jam, and Dinos. Other than the card art the games appear to be identical.

item.description:
Militaire is an army card game, consisting of 54 cards representing the ranks of the British Army.

The object of the game is to make up sets of three or four cards of a kind or a run of 3, 4, 6 or 7 cards in order of rank.

The first player to expose a complete hand comprising:
a) Two sets, or
b) a set and a run, or
c) an unbroken run of 6 or 7 cards,
wins the round and scores bonus points.

Old Polish game. Each player becomes an explorer in the tropical jungle. Pawns can move only in straight lines, you cannot jump over another pawns or "dangers of the jungle". However, the amount of fields covered in one move is not limited. After finishing a movement player picks up one adjacent tile. It can be:

- a desired object or animal, helpful in explorations (elephant for example)
- object scoring VP
- "danger of the jungle"

One player is not a usual explorer. Instead he plays the role of the "jungle". He aims to trap the players (by guarding the exits). When a "danger" tile is discovered, it enters the maze and "jungle" player is able to move it from this moment.

In any moment players acting as "explorers" may exit the jungle. They count VP on gathered tiles. At the end of the game (when everybody left the jungle or is not able to do it). The player acting as "jungle" earns VP for:

- every tile, that has not been discovered
- every VP tile gathered by trapped players, who did not leave the jungle.

Player with the most VP is the winner.

item.description:
This is a simple children's game with the theme of pirates collecting treasure from an island.

Each player begins with an individual pirate game board. Players place the well illustrated treasure pieces and deck of pirate cards on the larger game board representing the island. Players take turns drawing a pirate card and following the instructions on the cards, if successful you get variable amounts of treasure as rewards for the tasks to add to your pirate hoard. When all treasure is collected from the island, the player who has collected the most treasure wins!

name.value: Battle to the Gates of Hell

item.description:
Battle to the Gates of Hell, Bunker Hill June 17, 1775

On the night of June 16th, 1775, Colonel William Prescott of the Massachusetts Army of Observation and his regiment were ordered out onto Charlestown Peninsula under cover of darkness to erect fortifications in preparation of a forthcoming British attack there. Fortune had conspired with the Americans that June in the form of a superior espionage network, allowing the Americans to control and fortify the high ground before the British were even on the peninsula.

Units come in four colors and comprise two different armies.
The Massachusetts Army of Observation is represented by blue colored pieces. Units of the British army are represented by
red, orange and beige colored pieces.

Turning the Tide - The Battle of Bemis Heights (October 7, 1777)

The Battle of Bemis Heights (October 7, 1777) is a two player simulation of the second Battle of Saratoga in the American Revolutionary War. Although conflicts between the Americans and the British occurred throughout the day of October 7, this simulation’s focus is over the skirmish at Barber’s Wheatfield. For the purposes of this game, a hexagonal grid map is provided and used to regulate movement and combat. The game map is presented in a standard North-South format. The map covers an area approximately 1650 yards wide and 900 yards high, and thus each hex is representative of approximately 66 yards. The game has six turns which represent intervals of ten minutes. A series of counters are also provided representing particular units for both the British and American forces.

The Battle of Brunete (Spanish Civil War)
5 – 25th OF JULY 1937

The Brunete Campaign was the first Republican offensive in the Spanish Civil War after the failure of the Nationalist forces to conquer Madrid. An attack in the Brunete area, west of Madrid, was intended to relieve the capital from its siege under the Nationalists. However the campaign turned out to be a debacle with little success after initial breakthrough. 
The Battle of Brunete is a war game system simulating the Brunete battle, which was one of the crucial battles between the Nationalist and Republican forces in the Spanish Civil War. The Battle of Brunete simulation was designed for two players, one controlling the Republican units, representing the Loyalists, Anarchists, Communists, Liberals, and various International Brigades which were supported by the Soviet Union and the other player controlling the Nationalists, mainly Franco’s army, supported by German and Italian Fascists.

The game set consists of one “17 x 22” inch map sheet and one counter sheet of 90 counters (units and markers). Additionally players will need a 6 sided die for combat resolution.

This is a VERY simplified version of a Cosmic Wimpout style of game. Each player makes up to three rolls of the six specialized dice that make up the game's components. The player rolls trying to produce a carousel, a jumping horse, and a chariot - in that order. If the player manages to get all three, the rest of the dice can then be scored. Players who don't get all three score zero, while a perfect score of three brass rings would be 15. Scores are referred to as "the length of the ride."

item.description:
Welcome to the cannibal village of Tpoc! 
 
 Disaster befalls the village when the latest chief of the village has died! Play the role of an ambitious young cannibal who wants to become the next chieftain by finding out the issues that are the most important to the members of the tribe. You need to both convince the majority that you have their best interests in mind, and serve those who support your rivals at your next meal. Once all the villagers who will be on the tribal counsel are identified, they will hold a vote for the next chieftain of Tpoc. Finally you will learn if the villagers will raise you to the position you deserve.., or if you have fallen out of favor, and into flavor!

TPOC (The Politics of Cannibals) is a card and tile driven game for 3 - 5 players. You will play cards from your hand to the table before you to show your political "Platform." As the game progresses, tiles will be drawn from a bag to indicate how certain members of the tribe feel on one of 6 different issues such as (Religion, Farming, Labor, Trade, Cultural Identity, and Warfare.) Does a villager dare to challenge you? throw them into the POT! Each player must also be aware that at any time, one of the leaders of these six areas may decide to endorse the strongest candidate in their given area. 
 At game end, the player whose platform cards best match the tiles in play wins the game.

item.description:
The time is January 27th 1945.

Allied Command HQ
Excerpts from the Wolf Group Briefing
Without cause the Germans winter offensive through the Ardennes Forrest has abruptly come to a halt. Along the entire front, hordes of refugees have flooded into Allied camps all telling the tales of the dead coming back to life. Something has gone horribly wrong and zombie German Army humanoids, known as Kroids, are attacking with organized military efficiency.

- Who is leading the Kroids?
At this time we have no idea who, or what, is controlling or leading these Kroid forces. Reports have led to speculation that the leader of the Kroids is a summoned demon that was resurrected or awakened by the experiments of the SS Project Diabolus team at Castle Wewelsburg in Germany.

- Where do the Kroids come from?
All we know at the moment is that they are the reanimated remains of fallen soldiers or zombies – but not the mindless zombies seen in the Dracula movies we watched in the theaters as kids. Instead, these zombies appear to independently think and communicate. As they attack and kill our troops their ranks grow in numbers. What we do know is that a dead soldier, in any condition, burned, missing limbs or shot all to hell will, if not 'finished,' rise as a Kroid within 24 hours. A 'finished' corpse is one that has had its head removed.

- Why are the Kroids here and what do they want?
Sadly we have no idea. We believe this is the result of same wacky Nazi secret weapon experiment gone horribly wrong and we will just have to deal with it as best as we can. We do know that a Nazi machine called the Cyclomatron was built and activated by a team of SS scientists and engineers working at Castle Wewelsburg in Germany. Somehow this machine is the power behind these Kroids.

- How do we defeat the Kroids?
To date our strategy has been one of attacking the Third Reich's ability to wage war. We have been very successful in dismantling their infrastructure by destroying factories, refineries and transport. We have denied them the ability to manufacture and deploy the tools of war. The Kroids have no supply lines and they pick their tools of war up off the ground. They do not need to eat; they do not need to sleep. Their machines do not run on gas and ball bearings. Simply put, we have to change our entire strategy. As commanders you must think with your head. A casualty in your command is a new recruit for the Kroid army. The orders you have already received detail our current strategy, which is one of containment. Until further notice we are going on the defensive.

name.value: Clash of Steel: The Card Game (Fantasy Edition)

item.description:
From Publisher's Site:

Clash of Steel the Card Game (Fantasy Edition 1.0)

Rounding out our suite of games, this card game is quick to learn and play. Each game lasts ten game turns. For two to four players, it features a common deck and a variety of creatures to keep things interesting. Players collect resource cards to win, and attack each other with creature unit cards, augmented by number cards. Optional house rules are given to make gameplay more challenging.

16 Different Creature Unit Types 
12 Different Resource Card Types

Which country is the Giant Panda native to: Japan, China or India? Discover how much you really know about the natural world as you play the Planet Earth Card Game.

Based on the BBC series of the same name, this card is an educational card game, suitable for all ages.

Snow Tails is set in the snowy world of the Arctic Circle, where brave sledders compete in a test of skill and endurance. Action is fast and furious and not all sleds may make it to the finish. Huskies only have one setting and that is full speed! Hang on to your furs, the reins, your sled and anything else you can get hold of.

The game contains modular track pieces which can be fitted together to form different courses. Players have their own Dog Decks which they draw from and play onto their sled mat. Movement is rarely in a straight line as the sled may drift left or right. Losing control or speeding into a corner results in Dent cards being acquired which will limit a player's hand size.

The game features a fun and original movement mechanism.


Game Summary 
Race courses are built randomly. Players each have a dog sled with 2 dogs (initially valued 3 each) and a brake (also 3). Each player has the same deck of cards (5 sets of cards 1-5, shuffled) from which they draw a hand of 5 cards.

On your turn, may play 1-3 cards of the same value to these 3 locations (dog1, dog2, brakes). Forward speed (and distance moved) = dog1 + dog2 - brake + bonus (=position in race) if (dog1 = dog2). Lateral movement distance = dog1 - dog2 (move to the side with the stronger dog). Certain parts of the track have speed limits; you take damage if you exceed them, or if you run into obstacles (ice patches, side of track, etc.). Damage = cards that take up space in your hand (so 5th damage --> out of the race!).

The first player to cross the finish line wins!

item.description: Be the first player to get to the level 5 center of the board to win. Along the way, answer questions about the great town of Oregon, IL

Peaced Off! is a small cardgame, produced limited numbers, mostly as a present given to business acquaintances.

It is a simple trick taking game, with a scoring system based on collecting sets of matching cards, including nuns, that score negative points, unless you collect them all.

item.description: A set of war-game skirmish rules for running anime/manga style miniatures combat games. You can run any sort of games based on your favourite anima show. It is primary a combat game, but also allows you to run games as a campaign and give you a few ideas on how to add element of role-playing.

Combat 3000 are a set generic science fiction 25mm infantry combat war game rules, written by Richard Halliwell and Richard Priestly.

There was also one supplement; Combat 3001 (or A Fist Full of Credits), which added some advanced rules and rules for vehicles.

item.description:
Ball and Chain is a set of fantasy skirmish rules for 15mm and 25mm scale miniatures.
They are purely a generic set of rules which has a design system that lets you to decide on what type of troops you want. It has also a magic system and ideas on monsters.
Privacy 2 is the sequel of Privacy. 90 new Questions will bring new incredible truths about your friends. And you won't believe your ears again!

item.description: A free hex and counter boardgame of the Battle of Greenbrier River. An easy and quick wargame for beginning users, originally designed as part of the, 'Historical Series of Free War-games for Paperworlds.com"

A free hex and counter boardgame of the Battle of Manila Bay. A light boardgame simulating the battle between Spanish and American Forces in the Philippines. Originally designed as part of the, 'Historical Series of Free War-games for Paperworlds.com"

Mattel's Disney themed variation of Scrabble. The tiles come in the shape of Mickey Mouse with the value in the right ear and the racks are slightly glittery. The rule book is specific to this edition and grants a triple word score if the word DISNEY (not allowed in conventional Scrabble) is played, and a double word score if the name of any Disney character is played. The rule book includes an explicit list of characters from ARIEL to ZURG.

“Card game based on the Games Workshop Game called Man O' War.”

Each player constructs a fleet from one of the ship lists, with each player using an equal number of points. There are ships for the Bretonnian, Empire, Dwarf, High Elf, and Orc fleets. The object of the game is to destroy all of the ships in the opposing fleet.

“The Matrix: Movie theme. Board game for 4 players.”
Each player choose to play one of the four Factions: The Architect, Mister Smith, The Merovingian, or Zion & the Oracle. Each Faction has a Special Ability

The game is played using a standard chess board or other 8x8 grid, a standard deck of playing cards, six-sided dice, and a set of stackable tokens of a unique color for each player.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of the opposing Agents.

“The Matrix: Movie theme. Card game for 2 players. One player is the Humans. The other player is the Machines.”

Each player uses a unique deck. Both decks include Character and Event Cards. In addition, the Human Deck contains Mission Cards. The Mission Cards are assigned a Mission Point value ranging from two to five.

“Objective: The Human player wins if he accumulates 20 Mission Points. (Neo hacks the Mainframe & makes a truce with the Machines). The Computer player can win in 3 ways: 1. Kill Neo, 2. Destroy the Nebuchadnezzer with Extermination Units, 3. Destroy Zion with Robot Army (Accumulate 20 Time Counters)”

A card game of medieval combat between individual warriors. For two or more players. The cards represent weapons, weapons that can parry, basic attacks, opportunity attacks, shields, armor, and defenses. A player whose warrior receives twenty or more damage points is knocked out of the game. The last player remaining is the winner.

“Card game for 2+ players. Players are Men in Black, protecting the Earth from the Scum of the Universe.”

The game uses a custom card deck containing nine types of cards: Agents, Major Aliens, Lesser Aliens, Clues, Plot Twists, Helpers, Equipment, Weapons, and Events.

“Victory: The first player to defeat 3 Major Aliens is the winner.”

“Historical simulation of the WWII battle of Midway. Two player set piece Dice game. One player is the Japanese, the other is the Americans. Flowcharts are used instead of Maps.”

Each player controls squadrons of aircraft which are moved on the player’s flowchart. Spaces on the flowchart represent different activities and locations: Carrier, Takeoff, Patrol, Search, Second Search, Attack, and Return. A separate Carrier Box flowchart has spaces related to carrier activities and locations: On Deck, Takeoff, and Refuel/Rearm.

The game portrays the following types of US and Japanese aircraft: Wildcat, Devastator, Dauntless, Avenger, Buffalo, Marauder, Vindicator, Catalina, Flying Fortress, Zero, Kate, Val, and Judy.

The object of the game is to destroy all of the opponent’s carriers.

“Fantasy Card Game for 2 or more players. Each player controls a Magical Kingdom at war with all the others.”

“Deck: Players share a common deck. The deck has 3 types of cards mixed in: Strongholds, Hordes, and Mighty Magics.”

“Stronghold Cards: These represent gains in territory. The card will have a Name, Force Value, Notes, and Recruitment Cost. Players can only defend with Strongholds. Strongholds are used to secure victory.”

“Horde Cards: These represent creatures, armies, monsters, heroes, and mages at your disposal. The card will have a Name, Force Value, and Recruitment Cost. Players can attack and defend with Hordes.”

“Mighty Magics: These cards will have a Name, Recruitment Cost, and special instructions.”

“Victory Conditions: The first player to begin his turn with 15 or more Force worth of Strongholds wins.”

A game of combat involving fantasy miniatures, played on a chessboard. Each player has an army of sixteen figures, composed of two Leader Minions, four Greater Minions, and ten Minor Minions. The game includes statistics for 21 Leader Minions, 57 Greater Minions, and 39 Lesser Minions. Most Minions have one or more special abilities. In addition, some Minions can cast spells, allowing them to draw a certain number of Spell Cards at the start of each game.

The object of the game is to destroy all of the opposing Leader figures.

“Espionage card game for 2-6 players. Players try to complete missions with their agents.”

The game uses a custom deck of cards of eight different types. The cards and their general usage is as follows: Agents (able to go on missions), Missions (must be completed to win), Locations, Obstacles (must be overcome for a mission to be completed), Experience (permanently improve an agent’s capabilities), Equipment, Contacts (temporarily improve an agent’s capabilities), Events (affect game play in a variety of ways).

“Alignment: Each player decides whether their organization is good or bad. In a two player game, players must be of opposite alignments.”

“Nemesis: Each player picks one opponent to be their nemesis. The nemesis must be of the opposite alignment.”

“Object: At the end of the game, the player with the most mission points wins.”

“Fantasy version of Go. (Mogo = Monster Go) For 2 (or more) players.”

The game is played on a 10x10 grid using counters to represent Units, Locales, Relics, Enchantments, Sorceries, and Modifiers.

There are three ways to win the game. Getting seven counters in a row is a Tactical Victory. Capturing twenty or more enemy counters is a Logistical Victory. If the board is filled up, whoever controls the most counters earns a Strategic Victory.

“Card game for 2-6 players. Art Museum Theme. Each player controls their own Museum of Fine Arts. Players compete to acquire the most and best Art collections. The player to score the most points at the end of the game wins.”

The game is played using two custom decks of cards -- the Revenue Deck and the Collection Deck.

The Revenue Deck is composed of sixty cards in six suits reflecting different sources of revenue: Endowments, General Revenue, Restricted Gifts, Government Funding, Memberships, and Grants. These cards are used to bid on Collections in the Bidding Phase.

The Collection Deck is composed of seven suits reflecting different collections of artwork: Ancient, Classical, Early Western, Non-Western, Late Western, Modern, and Contemporary.

"Simple Card Game for 2 players. Simulates a fight between 2 Napoleonic armies. Easy to make: Only 10 card types."

"The Deck: Players share a Common deck. 10 card types x 4 = 40 card deck." The card types are General, Cannon, Cavalry, Light Infantry, Line Infantry, Grenadier Infantry, Guard Infantry, Ready, Aim, and Fire.

"Morale: Each player starts with 20 Morale. Use coins or dice or tokens to keep track of Morale."

"Victory: Reduce your opponent to zero Morale."

item.description:
“Board & Card Game for 2+ players. Based on the Myth series of books by Robert Asprin. The series takes place in a humorous fantasy universe of Dimension-hopping Demons, Magicians & Con-Artists.”

The players represent main characters from the series: Isstvan, Garkin, Massha, Frumple, Diz-Ne, or Aahz & Skeeve. The characters have special abilities and limitations. Each character is rated for Guile, Savvy, Fight, and Magic. The players travel around a circular board, visiting bazaars, scamming the locals, and facing missions.

“Victory: The first player to accumulate 25 Reputation Points is the winner.”

"Card game for 2 players. Naruto Theme: A Combat between 2 Ninjas." Inspired by the Japanese cartoon character Naruto.

The players choose to play one of eight different characters:
Naruto, Susuke, Sakura, Kakashi, Zabuza, Haku, Rock Lee, and Garaa. Thirteen statistics are given for each character: Rank, Sex, Village, Attack, Defense, Stamina, Speed, Tactics, Skill, Convert, Taijutsu, Ninjutsu, and Equipment.

The object of the game is to reduce the opponent's Stamina to zero.

"2-5 player card game with WWII theme." The players represent the Axis (Germany, Japan) and Allied (Britain, Russia, America) forces.

Each nation has a custom deck of cards, which represent various sea, land, and air units used by the nation. The cards are divided into four categories: Action, Leader, Permanent, and Modifier.

Leader Cards and Permanent Cards represent improvements or advantages that provide various bonuses to the nation until the card is destroyed. Action Cards typically represent strategies, tactics, defenses, or events. They are played when appropriate and then discarded. Modifier Cards are bonuses that must be attached to a specific unit.

The object of the game is to reduce your opponents to zero Power Points. Each player starts with twenty-five Power Points.

"Card game for 2-4+ players. Players are reporters for rival newspapers."

Cards are played from a hand of ten to form news stories. Circulation points are awarded based on how many cards can be used to form the story - from one card (one circulation point) to ten (one hundred circulation points).

"The player with the most circulation points at the end of 5 turns wins."

"Card game, about, you guessed it, nose picking."

The deck includes five types of cards: Pick, Booger, Special, Negate, and Bonus Point Modifier.

"Victory: The first player with a collection of 100 Magic Nose Goblin Points (MNGP) wins."

"Card & Dice game for 2-4 players. Based on the Orkworld RPG by John Wick. Each player controls a Tribe (Gathum) of Orks." Solo play rules are also included.

"Use Metal or plastic figures to represent your Population. 1 Figure = 1 Ork."

The game also uses a custom deck of cards composed of nine types of cards: Foe, Weapon, Armor, Tribal Item, Personal Item, Personal Modifier, Tribal Modifier, Battle Event, and Non-Battle Event.

The players attempt to build their tribes into effective fighting forces in order to defeat Foe cards played on the tribes by other players. Defeating a Foe card increases a Tribe's Fame Points.

In addition to taking casualties in battle, other circumstances will affect the population of the players' tribes. Each turn a hunting roll is made to determine whether conditions will result in any increase or decrease in population.

"Victory: The first player to accumulate 25 Fana (Fame) points and survive is the winner."

A fantasy game for two players. The object is to capture the opposing Overlord to become the one true Overlord. Each player starts with one each of the following pieces: Overlord, Hero, Wizard, and Dragon.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Four of each of the following features are randomly distributed on the board: Castles, Towers, Dragon Lairs, Bottomless Pits, and Mountains.

The Pits and Mountains represent barriers. The other locations are places where units may be recruited - Heroes from Castles, Wizards from Towers, and Dragons from Dragon Lairs.

“You made a wrong turn & fell into the Abyss. Now you must fight your way out. Solo card game.”

The game uses two card decks – the Holy Deck and the Demon Deck. The Holy Deck contains the attack and defense cards that will be used by the player. The Demon Deck contains cards representing the demons that are attacking the player and the locations in Hell that the player is traveling through.

“Victory: You win if you defeat all the Demons in the Demon Deck. You lose if you are ever reduced to zero or less Life Points. Your final score is the number of Life points you have left.” The player starts the game with twenty Life Points.

“Card game for 2 players. Each player is a Greater God trying to build up his pantheon.” The monsters, gods, and events appear to have been inspired by tales of mythology from various European countries.

The card deck includes seven types of cards: Gods, Armies, Heroes, Priests, Monsters, Miracles, and Temples. Tokens are used to keep track of Worshipers. The players use their armies, heroes, and monsters, and priests to attack the opposing forces and temples. These actions may also result in the elimination or conversion of opposing Worshipers.

The object of the game is to have seven or more God Cards in play on your side. God Cards are put into play by expending Faith Points. The Faith Points available to a player are determined each turn based on the number of Worshipers, Priests, and Temples controlled by the player.

An abstract strategy game played on a large 5x5 grid. The game also requires a different colored pawn for each player and a standard deck of playing cards.

At the start of the game, the deck is shuffled and a card is placed on each of the twenty-five spaces on the board. The players then select their starting corners and place their pawns.

As the players take turns moving their pawns, they get to keep the card (if any) from the space that the pawn was moved from. The game ends when all of the cards have been collected.

The object of the game is to make the best five card Poker hand from the playing cards collected by the player.

"Card & dice game for 2+ players. Each player is a pawnshop owner."

The custom card deck used in the game contains two types of cards - Item Cards and Event Cards. Each Item Card has three values on it: Pawn, Interest Fee, and Sell. The Event Cards reflect random events that help or hinder the players.

"Winning: The first player to accumulate $10,000 is the winner."

The designer notes: "I used to work in a pawnshop. Saw some crazy stuff."

"Players control Pirate ships in search of plunder & adventure. The first player to accumulate 7 Treasures and have them stored in their home port is the winner."

The units in the game are based on the fleets from the Warhammer naval game Man O' War. The players can control pirate ships from the Empire, Brettonian, Elf, Dwarf, Orc, or Chaos fleets.

A pirate themed strategy game played on a Backgammon board. The four quadrants of the board are referred to as Outer Sea (points 1-6), Great Sea (points 7-12), Middle Sea (points 13 -18), and Inner Sea (points 19-24).

There are three types of pieces used in the game – Pirates, Merchants, and Man-o-Wars. In addition, tokens are used to represent Gold Coins.

The Pirate piece is used to collect Gold Coins. While gold is in the Pirate ship it is subject to being lost or plundered. When a player bears gold off the board, it is placed in the player’s Treasure Chest where it is safe.

“The first player to accumulate 25 Gold Coins in his Treasure Chest is the winner.”

A card game of pirate plunder and adventure for two or more players. The object of the game is to be the first player to have a Buried Treasure pile worth twenty Gold or more.

The game is played with three decks of cards: Pirates Own Deck, Event Deck, and Plunder Deck.

The Pirates Own Deck includes three types of cards related to the pirate forces: Captains, Ships, and Crew. The Plunder Deck includes two types of cards: Treasures (having a Gold value) and Objects (provide an advantage when carried on a ship). The cards in the Event Deck are random events that can help or hinder players.

“Card game for 2+ players. Raid/Skirmish level Fantasy combat. Each deck represents one of the races found in the Outer (or Inner) Planes of the AD&D Universe. Currently available decks include: Githyanki, Githzerai, Mind Flayer, Beholder, Modron, Slaadi, Daemon, Deva.”

“Each player uses his own Primary and Secondary deck. Each deck is specific to a single race. Players also share a common Spell Deck & Psionics Deck.” Units depicted on the cards represent Monsters, Fighters, and Wizards.

“Victory: Defeat a Player by reducing him to zero Morale points.” Each player starts with fifty Morale points.

A card based game in which each player controls a plantation in Early America. The players compete to establish the biggest cotton, tobacco, sugar, rice, and indigo fields. The game is driven by a custom deck of cards. There are two types of cards in the deck: Events and Permanents. Permanents include Cash Crop Fields, Buildings, and Slave Quarters. Slave Quarters are required to support fields and buildings.

“Card game simulating the battle of Plassey 1757. One player is the Army of the East India Company. The other player is the Bengal Army. An Anglo-Indian Force of 3,000 men defeated a Bengal Army of 50,000 men.”

Each player uses a custom card deck. Each deck has five types of cards: Leader, Unit, Artillery, Defense, and Special. The cards depict elements of the historical campaign.

Each turn the players fight a battle by playing melds of cards. The meld having the higher total force value wins the battle. The winner of a battle takes one Territory Maker from the other player.

The object of the game is to control all five Territory Markers. At the start of the game the British have two Territory Markers and the Bengali have three.

A card game inspired by the first two seasons of the Power Rangers television series.

One player gets a Ranger Deck, the other player gets a "Bad Guy Deck." To play a game based on season one, the respective players use the Mighty Morphin Power Ranger Deck and the Rita Repulsa Deck. For season two, the White Ranger Deck and Lord Zed Decks are used.

The first player to win five hands wins the game.

"Two player card game of Super Powered Martial Arts Combat."

Each player starts out with 100 Hit Points and 10 Power Points. The object of the game is to reduce the opponent to zero Hit Points.

Cards are drawn and played to make or aid attacks. Each card has a Power Point cost. A basic hand to hand attack may be made without playing any cards. The basic attack costs one Power Point and causes 1d6 damage. Each turn that a player does not make an attack, the player gains 2d6 Power Points.

“Board game for 2 players. Race for the US Presidency. One player is the Democratic Nominee. The other is the Republican Nominee.”

The game uses a square track game board (11 spaces on a side), Money Tokens, Vote Tokens, two Pawns to represent the candidates, two six-sided dice, and three decks of cards (the Candidate, Campaign, and Election Decks.)

The object of the game is to have the most votes after thirty turns.

"Math themed Card game for 2-4+ players."

"The Deck: Cards are numbered zero to nine (0-9). There are 6 copies of each card. The Deck is composed of 60 cards."

The object of the game is to play a progression of three related numbers from a hand of eight cards. Seven types of progressions are acceptable: Basic, Algebraic, Prime, Exponential, Pythagorean, Fibonacci, and Geometric.

"Winning: The first player to make 5 Progressions wins."

"Board and Dice Game. American Prohibition 1920’s Theme. Players are smugglers transporting Alcohol."

The games is played on a circular track containing three types of spaces - source, establishment, and culture. The players earn Bankrolls (money) by buying Cases (alcohol) from Sources and transporting it to Establishments. Each Culture space has two Bankrolls placed on it at the start of the game. One Bankroll may be taken by the first two players to land on the space.

In addition to the three player pawns, there are three law enforcement pawns: Local Police, Prohibition Agent, and FBI Agent. These pawns may be moved by the player in lieu of moving the player's pawn. The Local Police confiscate Cases from Establishment spaces. The Prohibition Agent confiscates Cases from player pawns. The FBI Agent confiscates Cases from Source spaces.

"The Game ends when there are no Bankrolls left on any Culture spaces. The player with the most Bankrolls at the end of the game wins."

“Players are Psionic warriors trying to destroy each others minds and bodies. 2+ player card game.”

The game uses a custom deck of over 60 cards. The cards are divided into the following types: ESP, Mental Attack, Physical Attack, Special Mental Attack, Incapacitating Attack, Power, Regeneration, Defense, Mental Defense, and Physical Defense.

“Setup: Each player starts with 20 Physical points and 20 Mental points. Each player starts with 3 cards. Determine turn order by rolling high on 1D6. The first player to go must discard a card.”

“Object: Reduce your opponent to 0 Physical or Mental points.”

"Players are Therapists trying to cure their patients and themselves."

The game is played on a square track with 13 spaces on a side. Each player has a set of pawns that move around the board, one of which represents the player's therapist and the rest of which represent the player's patients. A player can have a maximum of five patients at one time. The player attempts to cure patients by reducing the Neurosis Points score for each patient to zero.

The game ends after exactly one hour.

"Winning: The player with the most Total Victory Points (VP) wins. Gain 10 VP for each patient you cure. Lose 10 VP for each patient you fail."

“Card game for 2 or more players. Players are medical professionals working in a hospital psych ward. Match drugs to diagnoses to score points.”

“The Decks: Players share two common decks: The Patient Deck, and the Treatment Deck.” Each of the 33 cards in the Patient Deck represents a patient. A Patient Card describes the patient’s diagnosis and treatment requirements.

The Treatment Deck contains two types of cards – Drug Cards and Contraindication Cards. The Drug Cards, a few of which describe “non-pharmacological treatment options”, are used to treat patients. “Contraindication cards represent ADR’s (Adverse Drug Reactions), Side effects, Co-morbid disease states, Drug interactions, Kinetics, Dynamics, Dosing, and Administration errors that would result in therapeutic failure.” The Contraindication Cards are used to negate Drug Cards played by opposing players.

“Setup: Each player starts with a hand of 5 random Treatment cards. Determine Turn order (the player with the longest name goes first).”

“Objective: The game ends when all patients have been successfully treated. The player, at the end of the game, with the most patients in his file is the winner.” A Patient Card is placed in a player’s file when the player completes the treatment of the patient.

"Card game for 2-4+ players. Theme: American Southwest Indian Pueblo Peoples."

The game uses a custom deck of 44 cards composed of six suits: Gods, Dances, People, Crafts, Homes, and Crops. The cards in each suit are numbered from 1 to 7. There are also two Misfortune cards in the deck: Raids and Drought.

"Victory: The first player to make 5 Melds wins the game. All 5 Melds must be of different types."

"Card game for 2 + players. Quantum Particle Physics Theme."

The game uses a custom card deck containing seven types of cards: Quarks, Carrier Particles, Baryons, Mesons, Leptons, Score Cards, and Special Cards.

The object of the game is to play various scoring combinations of cards. The winner is the first player to accumulate ten points.

name.value: Star Blazers: The Quest for Isacandar

item.description:
"In the year 2199, Earth is under attack from an alien race called the Gamilons. Gamilon planet bombs covered the earth with a deadly radioactive pollution and the surface of the earth is now unlivable. All life on Earth has moved underground. But even there, far below the earth's surface, the deadly radiation poisoning is beginning to reach them."

"Now all life on Earth has just one year left to live. But there is hope. On the planet Iscandar, there is a machine called the Cosmo DNA which can remove the radioactivity and restore Earth to it's natural state. The Star Force must travel 148,000 light years and back in just one earth year or all life on Earth will become extinct. But the Gamilons are determined to stop the Star Force at all costs."

"Star Blazers Card game for two players. One player uses the Star Force Deck. The other player uses the Gamilon Deck." The Star Blazers player must travel the 148 parsecs to the planet Iscandar before the start of turn 20 to win the game, otherwise the Gamilon player wins.

“Card game based on the Elf Quest Universe.”

Each player controls a tribe of elves, choosing from one of four types: Wolf Riders, Sun Folk, Blue Mountain Gliders, or Go-Backs. Tribes may include Character Members (represented by cards) and non-character members (represented by tokens). Each member of a tribe represents one Elf and, if it has one, its Bond Beast.

The custom card deck used in the game contains the following types of cards: Character, Land, Weapon Aid, Magic Aid, Ally Aid, Encounter, Food, and Event Cards.

“To win you must awaken the Old one. To do this you must travel a distance of 15 land cards. The last land you place must be a Mountain or Tundra (The Frozen Mountains). The last land you place is considered to be an entrance to the ‘Palace’.” Once there, the player must defeat the Guardian Trolls. The first player to do so wins the game.

“Very simple Miniatures rules. Ranges, distances, and movement abstracted. No record keeping, charts, or tables. Games resolved in under 10 minutes. These rules are based on Sci-Fi figures, but other types will work just as well.”

A miniatures game to be played with ten to twenty figures, or more. The players divide the figures into two opposing forces “based on aesthetic reasons.” Combat is resolved starting with weapons that can attack at extreme range, followed in succession by long range attacks, medium range attacks, short range attacks, and finally hand-to-hand attacks. A single six-sided die roll is used to resolve combat.

“Card game for 2 players. Players are each in control of opposing Quidditch teams.” Based on the magical sport from the world of Harry Potter.

In each Action Phase, the players make three piles of face-down cards which are later revealed simultaneously: the Bludger-Beater Pile, Quaffle-Chaser Pile, and Snitch-Seeker Pile.

To win the game, a player must have a specified force value in the Snitch-Seeker Pile, together with at least one Snitch and one Seeker Card. This causes the player to score 150 points and the game is over.

“Each player controls one character in a Raging Gun Battle.” The object of the game is to reduce all of your opponents to zero Hit Points.

The players pick one of the following “Character Archetypes”: Bruiser, Thug, Fem Fatale, Secret Agent, Mercenary, Black Ops Specialist, Hard-Boiled Cop, Enforcer, Hit-man, Rookie Cop, Assassin, Crime Boss, Gangster, Gun Nut, etc.

Each Character starts with ten Hit Points, one Gun Card, and two rolls on the Ability table. The abilities a character may have are: Tough, Danger Sense, Armed to the Teeth, Smart, Fast, Stealth, Resourceful, Lucky, Tactics, and Sharpshooter.

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are seven types of cards in the deck: Gun, Damage, Bullets, Card play, Attack Advantage, Negate Attack, and Extra Attack.

"The last epic battle in Norse mythology of Good against Evil."

The forces of the Good Aesir and Vanir battle against the Evil Giants. In addition to ten Norse Gods, the forces of Good are supported by Valkyries, Einheriar, Dwarves, and Elves. The forces of Evil are supported by Undead Hordes, Stone Giants, Storm Giants, Fire Giants, and Frost Giants. Each unit is rated for movement, strength, range, and any special abilities.

The game is played on a hex mapsheet depicting Asgard. The invading Giants line up on one side of the map. The forces of Good begin clustered around Valhalla. The object of the game is to destroy all opposing units.

“Card game for 2+ players. Easter Island Theme. Players control rival tribes trying to build the most and biggest Moai.”

The card deck contains seven suits of cards. Four suits are Resource Cards: Food, Wood, People, and Stone. Three suits are Event Cards: Raids, Huri Moai, and Disasters. The players form melds of Resource Cards to earn Moai Tokens.

The game ends when the players have gone through the deck three times. The player with the most Moai Tokens at the end of the game wins.

“Each player controls a party of Heroes traveling through the Northern Core of Ravenloft, the Demi-Plane of Dread.”

The game is played on a track ninety spaces long. The start and end spaces are Mist spaces, the other spaces are Domain spaces. Each named Domain is eight spaces long. There are eleven Domains, each of which has its own encounter table.

“The first player whose party (pawn) reaches the end space wins. You lose if all of your Heroes are killed.”

This is a fan-made game available at http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/RLQ.html

“Two Player Card Game. Based on the Book ‘Redwall’ by Brian Jacques”

“One Player represents Matthias the Mouse and the Defenders of Redwall Abbey. The other Player represents Cluny the Scourge and his Army of Rats.”

“Victory: Whichever player wins the Final Battle wins the game. The Final Battle is hand #13. If the Cluny player wins 3 hands in a row, the next hand is automatically the Final Battle.”

"Simple Napoleonic Miniatures Rules System. Uses Dry Erase Board, Markers, Dice, Risk Figures, and Regular Playing cards."

Scale: Each figure represents an infantry battalion, cavalry regiment, or artillery division. Each inch equals one half mile. One turn equals one half hour.

The game is played on a white dry-erase board. Terrain features are drawn directly on the board: "Green Patches for Woods. Blue for Water. Red Lines for Roads. Black Dots for Hamlets and Important Buildings. Irregular shaded areas for larger Urban Areas. Black Lines for Walls & Fortifications. Brown dotted lines for Hills."

"Use plastic figures from a Risk Game. This will include: Infantry, Cavalry, and Artillery. Each player also needs an HQ figure to represent the General."

"Get the most out of your trip to the Renaissance festival. Board game for 2+ players."

The game is played on an 85 space track. Each space is named for an event, activity, or exhibition. Examples include Glass Blower, Throwing Axes, Medieval Beer, Henna Tattoos, and Tarot Reader. Tokens are gained by landing on certain spaces.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get five of each type of Token: Craft, Game, Food, Acting, Music, and Education.

“Card Game. Simulates a Coup in a Developing Country. One player is the Government. The other is the Rebels.”

The game uses a deck of 140 cards. There are three types of cards in the deck – Unit, Dummy, and Modifier. Each card has a Force value, from zero (Dummy) to twelve.

The players draw hands of ten cards and fight a series of battles between units. This process repeats each turn. The game ends when one player has no units remaining, in which case the other player wins.

“Card game for 2+ players. Representation of a parliamentary debate. Based on Robert’s Rules of Order. Players compete to capture the Floor, which enables them to use up (gain) the most Time.”

“Victory: The player with the most Time Chips at the end of the game wins.”

“2-Player Pirate Strategy War Game. One player plays the rum runners. The other player plays the interceptors (rival pirates).”

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. There are seven types of units in the game: Swashbucklers, Swordsman, Slashers, Rum Runners, Musketeers, Pirates, and Mercenaries. The Rum Runner player has three Rum Runners, three Pirates, two Musketeers, and two Mercenaries. The Interceptor player has six Swordsmen, three Slashers, and one Swashbuckler. The Rum Runner player must get one Rum Runner to the opposite side of the board to win. The Interceptor must kill all of the Rum Rummer units.

The designer notes: “Game was originally designed to be played with the 37 piece plastic ‘Pirates on the High Seas’ set from D&D Distributing Inc. but is suitable for use with paper tiles.”

"Help Sailor Moon & the Sailor Scouts protect Earth from the Negaverse and the Negamoon."

Each player has a custom deck of sixty cards. One player uses the Space Scouts Deck, the other player controls the Nega Deck. Alternate sets of cards for the Nega Deck are used to reflect the events of season one (Negaverse) and season two (Negamoon).

The first player to win three hands wins the game.

"Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare."

The game uses two card decks, the Battalion Deck and the Tactics Deck. The Tactics deck is composed of maneuvers, formations, weapons, incidents, and terrain types. The Battalion Deck consists of thirty three types of military units (Infantry, Cavalry, and Artillery).

Cards are played on the table in battlefield positions representing the Left Flank, Left Center, Center, Right Center, and Right Flank positions. The first player to be routed from three of the five forward positions loses the game.

These rules served as the basis for the game Ready Aim Fire.

"Explore the mysteries of outer space with your trusty ship and intrepid crew."

The player is in command of a starship. The attributes of the starship and the skills of the crew are randomly determined by rolling on tables. The six member crew includes a captain, science officer, chief engineer, and three specialists (science, technical, or ship systems). The object of the game is to complete ten missions in the shortest time possible.

Missions are randomly generated by referring to tables. To complete a mission, the ship must face three random threats generated by rolling on tables. The crew and ship must have the skills and systems required by the threats and the mission to successfully complete the mission. If the player cannot complete the mission, the result is randomly determined by rolling on the failure table.

The game also includes three additional scenarios that expand on the basic game.

In the Drax Campaign scenario, the player must complete missions in order to win the war against the Drax. The player controls three starships. The attributes for these ships are generated by rolling on special wartime ship systems tables. Successfully completing missions makes a player victory more likely, while the failure to complete missions will lead to a Drax victory.

In the scenario A Long Way Home the starship must complete missions to reach a home destination. In the scenario A Campaign of Terror the starship must complete missions to defeat aliens threatening the human colonies.

A simple game of tactical spaceship combat.

Eleven types of ships are presented in the game. Each ship is rated for movement, hits, and the number of weapons systems carried. Seventeen different weapons are available, each rated for size, damage, range, and ammunition supply. Defensive systems which may be installed on ships include armor, missile defense system, and a self-destruct mechanism.

The players build fleets of ships which have an equal number of hit points, as set by scenario.

“Card game based on the Frank Miller Comic Sin City. 2+ Players.”

The game uses a custom deck composed of Event Cards and seven types of Character Cards: Event, Criminal, Agent, Psychopath, Hero, Victim, and Crime Boss. Each Character has a Fight rating and a Sin rating.

The players draw Character cards, place them into play, and use them to hunt down and kill the Characters of the opposing players. Sin Points are earned by killing Characters. The amount received depends on the types of Characters involved.

“Victory: The first player to accumulate 100 Sin Points is the winner.”

“Card and Board game for 2-4+ players. Alpine Ski Race theme.”

The game is played on a track 100 spaces long. The first space is the starting gate and the last space is the finish line. Each space is randomly assigned a number from 1 to 10. A standard deck of cards is used to govern movement of the ski racers.

“Victory: First player to reach the Finish line is the winner.”

“Card Game 2+ players. Players are trying to see who can get the best nights rest.”

Each player uses a Sleep Track marked with five stages ranging from Awake (stage 0) to Slow Wave Sleep (stage 4) to show which Sleep Stage the player is on. The players play Sleep Cards to advance to deeper levels of sleep. Wake Cards are played on an opponent to reduce the opponent’s Sleep Stage. At the end of each turn, a player gains a number of Sleep Tokens equal to the player’s current Sleep Stage.

“The game lasts 16 turns. Each turn represents Half an Hour. This would correspond to a full nights sleep of 8 hours.” The winner is the player with the most Sleep Tokens at the end of the game.

“Solve Mysteries with Scooby Doo & the gang of Mystery Inc. Card game for 2+ players.”

The players attempt to solve Mysteries by playing melds. A Mystery is solved by playing a meld containing one of each of the following types of cards: Scooby, Shaggy, Fred, Velma, Daphne, Villain, and Location.

“Winning: The first player to solve 3 Mysteries is the winner.”

“Card game for 2 players. Modern Naval Warfare Theme.”

The card deck contains four types of cards: Unit, Detect, Attack, and Counter. Units Cards are deployed as part of a player’s forces and remain in play until the end of the game unless destroyed. Detect Cards and Attack Cards are used to make attacks against enemy units. Counter Cards are used to counter attacks.

“The game ends when a player goes to draw a card, and there are no cards left in the deck. The player with the most deployed units at the end of the game wins.”

A card game for two or more players based on the Search for El Dorado, the legendary lost city of gold.
 The players form Expeditions by playing three card melds (one Leader, one Follower, and one Motivation). Each Expedition a player has in play attempts to make discoveries. Each Discovery Card gained by an Expedition is rated at one or two Discovery Points.

The game ends when the deck has been gone through twice. The player with the most Discovery Points at the end of the game wins.

A space race card game for two or more players. Each player controls a space ship. The first ship to travel 100 Astronomical Units wins the game.

The game uses a deck of sixty-five cards. There are four types of cards in the deck: Propulsion, Difficulty, Breakdown, and Repairs. Players advance by playing Propulsion Cards. Difficulty Cards can be played to negate specific Propulsion Cards. Breakdown Cards can be played on opposing players. A Breakdown Card stays in effect until it is repaired with the appropriate Repair Card.

“Welcome knave! The premise of Sorcery Chess is that the king is also a powerful wizard.”

The game is played using a standard chess set. However, the normal rules of Chess are altered by the use of spells by the Wizard Kings.

At the end of each player’s turn, the player rolls on a Spell Table and records the spell in a Spell Book. A player may only retain five spells at a time. Each turn a player may choose to move normally or to cast a spell. Most spells modify the way a piece can move. The rules also provide for Artifacts, which are like permanent spells, and Events, which occur immediately upon being rolled.

Expands:

 Chess

“Players control rival commercial colonies on a small piece of stable crust on a volcanic moon.” Watch out for the random meteor strikes!

The game is played on a 10x10 grid with spaces large enough to hold one game card. Each player starts out with one Outpost located in a corner of the map. The deck of 120 cards contains a variety of installations, resources, and volcanic sites. The players earn income from installations. Some installations are required to be adjacent to a certain site or sites in order to produce income.

“The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck. The player with the most credits at the end of the game is the winner.”

“Backgammon variant on a circular board with cards and a sci-fi theme. One player is the Terran Defense Force. The other player is the Evil Empire.”

The board is a circular track divided into twenty-eight spaces. There are four planet spaces equally spaced around the board. Each side has fifteen units marked with a force value from one to five. Cards can modify combat or provide a variety of other effects. The first player to occupy all four planet spaces is the winner.
